text: Epistasis is the interaction between genes at different loci.More precisely, the nonreciprocal (one-way) interaction of non-allelic genes: King R.C. Stansfield W.D. & Mulligan P.K. 2006. A dictionary of genetics, 7th ed. Oxford. p146 It was a term invented by William Bateson in 1909.Bateson, W. 1909. Mendel's principles of heredity. Cambridge. When Gregor Mendel did his experiments on the sweet pea, he chose seven traits, such as round vs wrinkled peas, and tall vs short plants. He found the plants had pairs of 'factors' (genes) which controlled their appearance (phenotype). However, one pair of factors never affected the other pairs. But with epistasis, the action of one gene does affect another gene, even one on a different chromosome. Use of the term has varied somewhat.Cordell, Heather J. 2002. Epistasis: what it means, what it doesn't mean, and statistical methods to detect it in humans. Human Molecular Genetics 11, 2463-2468 Its original meaning was quite narrow: for instance, a gene for no wings in Drosophila will obviously mask genes for any other aspect of the wings. In general, however, epistasis denotes any departure from independence of the effects of different genetic loci. == References == Category:Classical genetics
title: Epistasis
